did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library, Virginia Commonwealth University

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for use without restrictions.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Box/folder, Helena Lefroy Caperton Papers, M 3, Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library, Virginia Commonwealth University

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift to the Special Collections and Archives Department from Mrs. Barry Bingham and Mrs. Donald Stevens in 1988.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection processed in December 1972 and revised in 1987.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Helena Trench Lefroy was born on 18 August 1878 in her grandfather's (John Henry Montague) house at 118 East Franklin Street (Linden Row), Richmond, Virginia. Her parents were Sallie Watson Montague and Jeffrey Arthur Lefroy. As a child, Helena spent many summers with her father's parents at Aghaderg, County Down, North Ireland. Her recollections of these years can be found in "Some Reminiscences of an Ulster Childhood". She and her mother resided with the Montagues in Linden Row after the death of her father in 1883.

Helena married Clifford Randolph Caperton on "Wyndridge", Monroe County, West Virginia 16 November 1897. They had seven children. After 1920, Mrs. Caperton began to write seriously and had many articles and short stories published. "The Honest Wine Merchant" won the O. Henry Award in 1930 and the O'Brien Anthology of the Best Short Stories gave a star rating to "Lost Governess". She wrote regular book reviews for the Richmond Times-Dispatch and the Courier- Journal (Louisville, KY).
Helena Lefroy Caperton died after a short illness on 27 September 1962.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, manuscripts of short stories, articles, reviews, and other literary efforts, reviews of Caperton's works, bills and receipts, photographs and other papers relating to her career and family life (1918-1961). Includes correspondence with publishers and periodicals and material on Virginia and Irish legends and folktales, and social life in Virginia and England. Correspondents include William Rose Benet, Edward O'Brien, Dorothy Parker, Charles Scribner, Claude Swanson and Alexander Waddell.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged alphabetically then chronologically.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p:
Series I--Unpublished Fiction and Articles (n.d., 1924, 1928, 1931, 1934, 1939, 1947-1948, 1951)
Series II-- Receipted Bills and Canceled Checks (1924-1961, majority in the 1950s)
Series III-- Letters from Magazines and Publishers (n.d., 1920, 1923-26, 1929-1941, 1943, 1946-1947, 1949-1952, 1955, 1970)
Series IV--Family Letters, Fan Letters, Published Newspaper Articles and Reviews, Photographs (n.d., 1918, 1923, 1931, 1934, 1937-1939, 1943, 1949-1952, 1954-1955)
Series V--Irish Fairy Stories, Irish Childhood, The Richmond German, Sketches of Old Richmond, Assorted Short Stories and Articles (n.d., 1932, 1939, 1947, 1950-1953, 1958, 1960, 1970)
Series VI-- Printed Articles and Short Stories in Magazines and Newspapers (1902, 1921, 1924, 1929-1934, 1937-1939)
Series VII-- Artifacts (3 pieces)
